Posts.Content: Jan 15, 2014 09:40AM Gardengirl66 wrote: hi , like everyone else, it took about 6 weeks to start to feel almost normal again after my biopsy. I had lots of bruising as well . I also could feel a lump ,which I was worried about ....but my surgeon explained it was a swollen lymph node,a normal reaction , which he explained if he did the same procedure to himself or my husband ...their bodies. would react the same way . I also bruised a lot more with the biopsy ,than the partial mastectomy  and 3 lymph nodes removed. Wishing you all the best !
Posts.Title: Biopsy..lots of bruising Star13 SlowDeepBreaths

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2008 09:52AM GardenGirl65 wrote: I went out and bought a moderately priced electric razor (they can get expensive!) and started using it about a week before I started RAD. It did kind of sting a little bit at first. But I used it every day so my skin could get used to it before RAD. It's been working out fine for me. My RADONCO RN gave me one of those crystal thingies to use for deodorant. It works okay as long as I'm not sweating like a crazy person (guess that'll come after I start the Tamoxifen!) I cheat, and use regular deodorant on the week-ends. I figure I'm not actually getting RAD on the week-ends anyway ....
Posts.Title: Anyone use regular razor on pits during radiation? Stressin67 GardenGirl65

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2015 12:35PM Gardengirl66 wrote: hi mommy30, try to take a deep breath...and as soon as your doctors office open go in. Your doctor should send you for ultrasound and a biopsy . A biopsy is the only way to rule out IBC....I went through all this Oct. 2014. You might also have Cellulitist ....which is what I ended up being diagnosed with ....but both my doctor and oncologist said they have the exact same symptoms and visually you can not tell the differences.I had 5 biopsys samples done. I was put on a strong pencillian, twice,then it started to clear.....which took about a month to clear. It is scarey...both are serious situations....it also could be a rash from a bite....which is the first thing I was asked...or was I scratched. I was bright red, itchy, warm, orange peel, thickening of the skin, red bands... Please seek a doctors opinion , they really are the only ones that can figure it out. There are a lot of fabulous people on this site to talk to.... Till you get any results. Sending you big hugs and I will be thinking of you....hang in there...I know how you must be feeling .please feel free to message me. (((Hugs)))

I think psychologically, men are just different from us. Their solution to just about everything is, "Ignore it. It'll go away. Go to work. It won't be there when I get home." etc. I guess if they had cancer they would start working overtime just to run away from it! Paxton ~ you hit the nail on the head when you mentioned the fact that men typically want to "problem solve". They just can't understand that we actually want to cry about stuff sometimes! They act like tears are the worst thing that could happen to anybody! They automatically think they need to give us advice on how to fix the problem. They don't understand that's the last thing we want from them at that time! Poor guys. Honestly ... the female species really dropped the ball when they decided to let guys run the show. Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2008 03:12PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Pax ~ So sorry you're on stand-by. I know that must be very frustrating for you. When I had that nasty infection I only had three general RADs to go and 5 boosters. The doc offered to lot me start the boosters and hold off on the last two generals. But I said no. I'll just grit my teeth and get it over with. But I had the choice. Sounds like it's not even an option for you. Bummer! As far as feeling close to the techs at the clinic ... I wasn't all warm and fuzzy with them, but neither did I begrudge them anything. There was one gal that rubbed me the wrong way, but the rest of them were okay. Hey all ~ I used Silvadene cream on the split/infected skin. It cleared it up very fast. Of course I was taking an oral antibiotic at the same time. I think Silvadene is intended to kind of have a drying effect though. That's why they gave it to me to put on the infection. It was all oozy and contiuously damp. The Silvadene kind of dried it up so it could have a chance to heal. If you're putting on the entire breast, have you found it to be drying to your irradiated skin? Miss Lolli ~ I'll eat the ice cream AND slather it on! After all, I am a hedonistic, heathenistic, heretic as my mother loves to point out! Methusala ~ You poor grumpy thing you! That's okay! I think we are allowed to be a little cranky, don't you? Just hang tight girlfriend ... it'll get better soon. More ice cream in the meantime! And it's always better when you eat it in your warm fuzzy jammies!

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2008 08:09AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Miss Lolli ~ I just watched 13 going on 30 the other day! I loved it! Speaking of Pat Benetar's "We Are Strong"! LOL That movie was great. Thanks all for the congrats on getting closer to my nursing degree! The past two years have just flown by! I was afraid to take on the challenge when I first thought about going back to school, but I thought, "Where will I be two years from now if I don't go back to school? The same damned place I am right now!" So I went. And now look where I am two years later! I'm so glad I did it. I think it has set a good example for my kids too. To see mom doing something to improve upon life after the divorce instead of just burying herself in a pile of blankets (which is what I wanted to do)! I love this website! You gals are some of my best friends! On Spring Break this week. Got follow up appts with all my docs and will start on Tamoxifen. A little worried about how that will affect me ...

Spring Break is over and it was back to school for me today. Just 8 weeks to go! Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2008 08:28AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Thank you Lori ~ Yes ... the job of a CNA is very demanding - both physically and mentally. But it is also very rewarding. When a little, old lady, or cranky old man smiles their toothless smile at you, pats you on the hand, and says "thank you" it makes it all worth it. Like your daughter, I tried several different jobs after high school ... cashier, clothing store manager, bank teller, etc. I hated them all. Then on a whim I responded to an ad in the paper for a nursing home. I LOVED it! They trained me to be a CNA and I worked in nursing homes for several years. I went to work for a hospital after I got married and had kids, cuz the benefits and everything worked out better for me. That's when I decided to become a nurse. Had a few set-backs (divorce, single-parenthood, financial difficulties, etc.) but I was finally able to go back to school, and now here I am, just a few weeks away from graduating! I'm so proud of myself it's almost sinful! LOL! Had my second night of Tamoxifen last night. No S/E so far ... I'll see you over in the Tamoxi-train!

Posts.Content: May 20, 2008 12:21AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hi VBeegle ~ I finished RAD's in February, so I'm pretty well out of the woods now. But when I was in RAD's my nipple cracked, and split, and got infected with cellulitis. The seepage was a clear yellow at first but then turned cloudy. My doc gave me an oral antibiotic and a topical cream. It healed right up, and all of the burns and other skin issues disappeared quickly after RAD's stopped. But the skin on my breast is still very soft and tender ... like a baby's butt! And after wearing a bra all day, I notice moisture around my nipple ... like when you sit in the bathtub too long and get all pruney. I'm not sure if this will go away at some point or what. You might want to have the doc take a look at the drainage and maybe take a culture of it to see if it's an infection. In the meantime ... I took a soft, white, cotton T-shirt and cut it up into little squares and lined the inside of my bra with it to absorb the moisture. Maybe that will help you a little.
Posts.Title: seeping around nipple VBeegle VBeegle

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 09:32AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hey Paxton ~ Yeah, it sucks being in Dr's offices all the time. I've gotten into the habit of bringing my MP3 player along, closing my eyes, and just running away into the music. Somtimes a little Nirvana when I feel like telling the world to f**k off ... sometimes a little Enya when I feel spiritual. The nurses have learned to come over to me and gently touch my arm when it's my turn to go in. If they just stand there and call my name I won't hear them! We try to keep a positive attitude and hope for the best, don't we? But sometimes, late at night, your head starts buzzing and you start thinking about all the worse case scenarios ... Sucks, don't it?

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2008 10:47PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Nash ~ Give 'em hell girl! Methusala ~ Hang in there sweetie! It's an unpleasant journey, but a quick one. The Rad's started making me nauseated in week 2. It lasted through week 3, but after that it wasn't really nausea ... just kind of a heartburn feel. Unfortunately the fatigue only got worse as the treatments went on. I swear I perfected the art of instantaneous napping! It didn't matter where I was ... if there was a chair, I was in it and asleep! Had my first booster today. No big deal. I'm looking forward to the rest of my skin getting a break. My infection isn't looking much better, but I've only been on the antibiotic for 3 days now. I'm sure it'll clear up soon. Let's keep our chin up girls! Women have been the silent strength for centuries ... there's nothing we can't do!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Feb 7, 2008 11:55PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Miss Lolli's right ~ if he didn't run at the dx and hasn't disappeared yet, he must not be all that bad. My bf and I broke up a couple of months before my dx. While I'm sad and disappointed the relationship ended ... I'm glad it ended before I got the BC dx. If he would have broken up with me afterwards, it would have been excruciating! Nash ~ I'm on my way! We'll put the ice cream on top of the warm cinnamon rolls then wash it all down with our drink of choice! Paxton ~ If he's a keeper ... then by all means keep him! I'm still looking for one worth keeping. Or one who thinks I'm worth keeping! Sometimes I think it's just not gonna happen. I mean, I'm 42 years old for cryin' out loud. I closely resemble the Pilsbury Dough Girl (all white and squishy), and now I've got a BC sign hanging over my head! Oh well ... I've always got my ice cream and kitty cats ...
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Feb 12, 2008 04:03PM GardenGirl65 wrote: !!!!!! I'M DONE, I'M DONE, I'M DONE !!!!!!!             !!!!!Whoo-hoo!!!!! Didn't shed a tear either! Smiled the whole time I was returning my parking pass and getting my "Certificate of Completion". My infection and swelling are almost all gone now and my skin is starting to flake and peel. Still a little itchy, but not nearly as bad as it is during the middle of tx, as some of you girls are experiencing right now. I'm still terribly tired though. I guess my energy will gradually come back. I figure it took 6 weeks to burn me and drain my energy, so it'll probably take 6 weeks to recover. Hang in there girls! If I can do it, you all can too!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2008 04:10PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hey Marietta ~ congrats on the job interview! I'm sure it went well! Abbi ~ Just my personal opinion - which really only matters to me! But I don't think I'd say anything about the BC during a job interview. I mean, I would be honest if they asked if I had any health issues that may need special consideration. But if you're finished with surgeries, tx, etc. then the BC really shouldn't cause any current issue. m38 ~ Hi! Welcome! I had some pretty severe nausea for a couple of weeks. I also experienced dizziness. I think the dizziness was from being so tired, nauseated, and just generally stressed out. I think weeks 4 & 5 were the worst for me. The pain, nausea, and fatigue seemed to be at their worst then. I started feeling better in week 6 when I was having the boosts. I have been finished with treatment for two weeks now and I can't believe how fast I am healing! My skin looks great! I think in another week or two I'll be completely back to normal. The fatigue is slowly going away. Barbie and Paxton ~ I'm thinking of you and hoping you get over this rough spot. Hang in there! We all love you! There's hope kids! My skin is healing up so well and so fast! I'm starting to feel "normal" again! Well .... as normal as I ever was .

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2008 02:03AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Pax ~ I think I remember that commercial. I definately remember the Plop, plop, fizz, fizz thing! My siblings and I used to sneak over to a neighbor's house to watch TV. We didn't own one till I was about 9 or 10. My parents didn't want it to poison our minds! When we finally did get a TV, we were only allowed to watch PBC. Remember Mutual of Omaha's Wild Kingdom? I loved that show! Lori ~ No wonder I'm such a hedon now. I was deprived of TV as a child. No, but seriously ... about 10 years ago I realized that I had been living my entire life trying to please everyone else. My parents, my husband, his parents, my uppity "friends"... When my husband decided he didn't want the responsibility of a wife and kids anymore and walked out on us, I decided to start living my own damned life and everybody could just kiss my ass! I'm as poor as a church mouse, but I'm happier now than I've ever been in my life! I'll graduate from college in a couple of months, earn some real money, and live happily ever after! My ex, by the way ... is remarried for the fourth time and is just as unhappy as he ever was. He actually hit me up for a little extra-marital entertainment a couple of months after his last marriage! Can you believe the balls? I feel sorry for his wife, so I never said anything to her about it. She'll find out soon enough what a wienie he is. Abbi ~ I only have to go in for one follow-up exam with the RAD oncologist. One month after my final treatment. I wonder why you guys have to go in once a week?
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2008 01:47PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hey Theresa ~ Sorry your sisters were butt-heads about your bc. I've got a strained relationship with my mom and sisters too, so I can empathise. But I'm very lucky to have a couple of wonderful girlfriends that are so kind and loving and generous. Plus, I found this site at the very beginning of my dx. It has been very helpful to chat with other women who know exactly how I'm feeling, what I'm going through, etc. I'm glad you finally found us! Now we can help you get through it too! I'm a single mom also, with two teenaged boys! 13 and 16. I know exactly what you mean when you talk about the teenage attitude! In one five minute period they are decent, polite, loving kids. In the next five minutes they are rude, disrespectful, little jerks! They really are good boys and I'm thankful for their maturity and kindness as I go through this difficult time. But they are kids after all, and sometimes we have a melt-down around here!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 12:26AM GardenGirl65 wrote: I thought it kind of tickled when they were drawing on me! I bought an assortment of cookies and pastries from a local bakery that everybody around here loves. I wanted to have them make some cookies that looked like white, pink, and red boobs, but I put it off too long and it was too late for a custom order. Guess it's just as well. I suppose not everyone would have appreciated the humor.
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2008 08:44PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Congrats on the outcome of the biop Barbie! And in my humble opinion ... YES! There definately is such a thing as guarded thankfulness! I know exactly how you feel. You're afraid to let your guard down, afraid to get too comfortable, afraid that if you let yourself finally feel like everything is going to be okay, then WHAM! Something is going to happen! I'm not sure how to get past it. I guess we just need to keep talking to The Spirit and asking for help in dealing with our actual problems and our imagined ones too. I guess we just keep asking for help in achieving inner peace and do the best we can to work toward it. Pax ~ Glad it was only spark plugs. That sounds like a quick fix. Do you think we will ever feel "finished" with BC? I mean, I know at some point we will be finished with actual treatments, but we will have to maintain with follow-up procedures for the rest of our lives! And at the back of my mind I worry about something else going on that I don't know about, or hasn't been discovered yet, or whatever. Kind of like Barbie is saying ... is it paranoia or an actual, real "feeling" that something just isn't right? I definately believe in intuition ... but is our intuition thrown off guard because we've become paranoid about cancer?
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2008 06:06PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Snoring on the couch sounds like ever so much more fun than getting on the treadmill! I can't remember how long it's been since I finished up treatment! 3 weeks? 4? Anyhoo ... the tan is gone now and the soft "baby-butt" skin is starting to get back to normal too. The nipple is still a lighter shade of pink than the other one, and the whole breast is a tiny bit smaller than the other one. It's full of lumps and bumps and dips ... I don't know how I would ever find an abnormal lump in there! Oh well ... nobody will notice. They'll all be staring as Miss Lolli pulls that toilet paper off her bizarre colored shoe! Man! I miss the 80's! How high did your bangs get girls? I only got up to about 2 1/2 inches.
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2008 03:00AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Thank you Miss Lolli ~ Actually, the divorce was several years ago. It took me a couple of years to come out from under the blankets. But I came out with a BANG! By the way ... as a hedonist in training, the first thing you need to learn to do is to play with your boob as much a possible! Get familiar with that new lumpy, bumpy thang! Barbie ~ I think I'm five weeks out of RAD now. My itching stopped by week 2, the nipple pain was gone by week 3 or 4, and the lightning bolts have turned into to tiny little buzzes that only hit every now and then. I don't actively ache, but if I have to reach up over my head, or reach behind me I can feel the tough tissue on the inside stretch and that hurts. Also, if I accidently lean against something, roll over on my tummy in my sleep, or if my cats step on my boob ... WOW! I get a quick, painful reminder! I hope you get to feeling better! I go to see the surgeon and medical oncologist tomorrow for follow-up. Will be getting the Tamox prescription. Follow up with radiation oncologist on Thursday. I think I'll be scheduling for my first follow-up mammo through the surgeon's office. And I think I remember an MRI is supposed to be scheduled too. At the time of my diagnosis, there was a "iffy" looking place on the opposite breast, but all mammo's and MRI's came back negative so we decided to take another look after recovery from this one.  Wish me luck girls!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

We have been having so much fun! I am so bogged down with homework though! I need to get back to it, but just wanted to pop in and say hi all!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2008 09:24AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hi All ~ I'm a little worried about a spot on my back girls. I had basal cell carcinoma removed from my left forearm several years ago. And then, of course, this BC ordeal. But, a couple of weeks ago I had a little itchy bump on my back. It has grown to the size of a nickle, is raised, dry, scaley, and still itchy. My family practice doc took a look at it and said it might be some kind of hive, but it's strange that there's only one. And I haven't used any new products, or done anything that might cause an allergic reaction. He told me to take an antihistimine and he gave me some cream to put on it. It doesn't seem to be helping. He said I will probably have to come back in for a biopsy. Yikes! Ya wanna know the silliest part of it? It's right next to, and partly under a part of my tattoo and I don't want my tatto to get messed up! Isn't that silly of me to be worried about that? Tell me not to worry girls. Carry me through this.

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 12:14PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Paxton! You crack me up! Love the Cat In The Hat. And hey - chocolate moles sound great to a hedonist like me. Just lick 'em off girlfriend! But seriously ... I know what you mean about panic. I had skin cancer back in '97 and have been vigilant with the sunscreen ever since. I didn't even make the connection about the skin cancer and the breast cancer till my oncologist said something about me being "at high risk for cancers". Plural! CancerS! It hit me all of a sudden ... I HAVE had two different cancers. OMG! Have I just been walking around with my head up my ass? Or am I in a total state of denial? Now I'm all freaked out about every tiny little mole, lump, bump, ache, or pain. And as The Cat In The Hat says ... I've got lots of all of those since I'm getting older. Geesh ... I think I need to start drinking! BTW ... follow up appts' with all three dr's went great. Will go in for mammo and sono in May. I thought I was going to be doing it this week, but they all said at least three months after rads. Hmmm ...

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2008 02:40AM GardenGirl65 wrote: 12954, I'm sorry you're having such a tough time of it. You're right ... it does suck! Big time! I had DCIS taken out with lumpectomy ... a BIG lump, taken out of a SMALL breast! I've got an indentation on the side of my breast now, and my areola is kind of pulled over to the side a little. It's not too horrible though. If you're already frustrated with the RAD process, I'm sorry to say you might get totally fed up with it after it actually starts. The treatments themselves aren't bad ... but going every single day sure does get monotonous. And the SE suck. I mean, there's nothing about the SE that have actually kept me from living my day-to-day life, but they definately create a minor to moderate glitch in the flow of things.   I'm half-way finished with my 30 treatment plan. Rant all you want. Goodness knows my friends have heard enough ranting, whining, cussing, and everything else out of me! Every now and then ya just gotta throw a good old-fashioned fit! I think it's good for you!

It's interesting to watch the progression of the redness. Now I think I'll take a pic once a week to track the healing. Trish ~ I can understand how you would want to just get it all behind you with no reminders. Isn't it interesting how many different personalities there are and yet we are all dealing with the same thing more or less? Abbi ~ I ordered an assortment of cookies, canoli's, and brownies from this wonderful bakery near the hospital. I was just too darned tired to bake anything myself. And honestly ... I don't think I've fired up the old stove more than a dozen times in the past two years that I've been working on my nursing degree! My poor kids have been living off chicken nuggets, spagetti-o's, and mac & cheese! Thanks for all the congrats girls! I'm still really tired, but just knowing that I'm done with the RAD's has been such an psychological relief! If I had enough energy I think I'd almost feel giddy!

Posts.Content: Mar 5, 2008 03:56AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hey Pax ~ Yeah ... those are all big things to think about. It's tough to try to plan for, or invision your future when you're past and present makes you not so sure about what kinds of things will be sent your way in the future. Good 'ol American insurance! Can't get it if you're too sick, don't need it but gotta pay for it if you're well, get state aide taken away and be punished for trying to work and be a productive citizen ... Geesh .... there has got to be a better way! But I guess as long as the corporate sons a bitches and the political bastards stay in each other's pockets we all continue to get screwed. Okay, okay ... I'll get off my soap box now! Good luck Pax on coming to a peaceful resolution to your questions. I had my tubes tied prior to my BC diagnosis. Plus, I'm too old to be thinking about any more babies any way, so I can only imagine what it must be like for you and other women who have to make such a heart wrenching decision. I'm sending you some positive energy though! And hoping you find serenity. Love, Donna

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2008 01:02PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hi girls! I started rad the day after Christmas. Merry Christmas, huh? The actual tx ain't nuthin. Ya just lie there for a few seconds and get zapped. Don't know if it's all in my head or if I actually feel a slight "tightening" in my breast during the zap. I've had 10 tx so far. Haven't really felt too fatigued. Maybe a little. Am starting to feel mild to moderate nausea though. Didn't expect that. Isn't really bad though. My breast is starting to turn pink and is getting a little swollen. It feels like it's been scrubbed with sandpaper! I'm not even a third done with my rad series. I hope it doesn't get much worse!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Jan 31, 2008 08:25PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hi Girls ~ I've just got two more "general" RAD treatments then I start my "focused" boosters. I've got to have 5 of those. They're doing it right on my incision, and I've heard a lot of you girls saying that the boosters caused your skin to peel. I wonder if it'll make my scar worse? I'm so tired .... I just walk around in a half daze. I feel like a wet rag. I tried so hard to stay healthy throughout the RADs, but I came down with a cold anyway. My throat was already scratchy from the RADs now it hurts so bad I don't even want to swallow my spit! My breast is so burnt! The crease under my nipple turned all white and gushy looking (macerated), split and bled, and is now draining a nasty looking pus. My doc started my on an antibiotic ointment and an oral antibiotic. I'm just so damned tired .....
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2008 11:02PM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hang in there paxton! You'll get through it! When the fatigue fog lets up you can start slow. Spring is coming soon and we can walk outdoors ... smell the earth ... see the fresh green buds on the trees ... Ahhh .... Hey Trish, Marietta is right! Those weights ain't nuthin! Course, I haven't worked out in a long while, but I remember that I liked the weights. I was amazed at how quickly I saw a difference in the shape of my arms! I really need to start exercising again. I bought yogurt today at the grocery store instead of ice-cream. Just didn't cut it! Oh well ... I'm trying!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2008 06:30AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Thank you Lori for the happy dance! The itch is almost all gone, and the redness has turned to brown, flaky stuff that's peeling off like after a sunburn. The lightning bolt pains have greatly diminished and are fewer and farther between. I'm still very tired though. I have to go to clinicals and/or lecture each morning. I just go through it in a fog. Thank goodness I have a couple of very dear friends in the nursing program with me! They really carry me along sometimes. Then I come home and just pass out on the couch till suppertime. I manage to throw together some mac&cheese for the boys, then I go to bed. Poor guys .... they're really being neglected lately. I mean ... they're teenaged boys ... they don't want much to do with mom anyway! Unless they want to borrow the car or get ride someplace! They're such good boys. They are taking such good care of old puny mom! Hang in there gals! It can be done!
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2008 12:13AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hi Abbi ~ Well, I'm about 3 weeks out from my RADs. I'll have a couple of days of energy, then a day of fatigue similar to when I was having the RADs. The brain fog seems to wax and wane throughout the day. Seems like I'm brighter in the mornings and kind of fade as the day goes on. Like you, my skin has healed up very quickly. The fatigue and brain fog are slowly going away. I just keep worrying they might be permanent! Anyone out there who's a couple of years out? Am I permanently damaged from the RAD?
Posts.Title: Anyone starting Rads in January? Barbie7 Miss_Lolli

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 11:00PM GardenGirl65 wrote: The twelve hour shifts aren't so bad, now that I'm doing unit secretary instead of nurse's aide. After my surgery and first couple of weeks of RAD's I talked to my supervisor and told her I just couldn't do the NA job ... it was just too physically exhausting! I've been a CNA for 18 years, but I still just couldn't hack it. My super very generously let me cross-train as a unit secretary. It's mentally challenging, but I'm sitting at a desk all day. Much easier than the NA duties! I couldn't take a leave of absence cuz I'm a single mom and the only income source in my home. Plus ... of all times ... I needed to keep my insurance! Soooo ... I just plugged right along like the little engine that could. Many of my friends and family have marvelled at how "strong" I am. I really don't think it has anything at all to do with being strong. I simply have no other choice! I just have to do what I have to do, cuz nobody else is going to do it for me! I've had to be tough since I was 9 years old. I just don't know any better, I guess. I'll bet I'm going to be one of those cranky old ladies in the nursing home that swings her cane at the young little nurses! HAhaHAha! I guess since I'm going to be the nurse now, then they can pay for it later! P.S. Paxton eating beaver? Does anyone else see the sick humor in that, or is it just little 'ol heathen me? Sorry Pax ... I just couldn't leave that one alone!

Posts.Title: PARANOIA??? austin2k3 austin2k3

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 10:38AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hi Austin! You're not paranoid, you're proactive! You're not a crybaby, you're concerned! Good for you! I agree with Tender. Take that badboy to the doc and find out what it is. I'm full of lumps! All of 'em benign cysts. Have had a mamm and sono every year to keep an eye on things. Found DCIS that way. Caught it early cuz of my paranoia and crybaby-ness ... Oops ... I mean cuz of my proactive-ness and concern. Now it's gonna be mamm's, sono's, MRI's, etc. every 6 months for awhile. I know I'll be afraid each time I go in that they will find something. But I'll keep telling myself that I'll be GLAD if they find something cuz then it can't be hiding in there! I'll know about it and kick it's butt! Stay on top of it!
Posts.Title: PARANOIA??? austin2k3 austin2k3

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2008 06:38AM GardenGirl65 wrote: Hi girls ~ Just happened to pop in out of curiousity. (I just finished my 33 RADs). Swmmom, maryannecb is right about the Prednisone. I work in the health care field and will graduate in May with an associate nursing degree. While Prednisone isn't really a dangerous drug per-say ... it does cause a lot of unpleasant and possibly some permanent side-effects. If you can avoid it, you should. Good luck with the recovery girls! We just gotta hang in there! P.S. Maryannecb, I love the pink boxing gloves!
